title: ADR-002
text: ADR-002: Strategy for Handling AI Model and Provider Uncertainty Status: Accepted Context: The field of AI is volatile. The best model or provider today may be superseded tomorrow. Relying on a single provider creates significant vendor lock-in risk. Furthermore, pricing models can change, and providers could potentially shut down. This uncertainty is a major architectural risk. Decision: We will implement an AI Abstraction Layer (Adapter Pattern) for all interactions with external AI/ML models. This layer will define a generic, internal interface for specific tasks (e.g., predict_demand(location, time), analyze_damage(image)). The concrete implementation of this interface will handle the specific API calls and data transformations for the currently selected provider (e.g., Google Gemini, OpenAI, or a self-hosted model). Consequences: Pros: Decouples our core business logic from specific AI implementations. Allows us to switch AI providers or models by only changing the adapter, minimizing code changes and risk. Facilitates A/B testing of different models. Cons: Adds a minor layer of complexity and potential latency to AI calls. Requires disciplined maintenance of the abstraction layer as new AI capabilities emerge.

title: Scratch Notes
text:
1. Introduction & Business Context
MobilityCorp is a growing provider of short-term, “last-mile” transport solutions. Our fleet consists of electric scooters, e-bikes, and electric cars/vans. We operate primarily in dense city locations but are expanding our car and van services into suburban areas.
Our current operating model is as follows:

Customer Interaction: Customers use an NFC-capable smartphone app to sign up, locate, book, unlock, and lock vehicles.
Booking Logic:
Cars & Vans: Can be booked up to 7 days in advance for a specific duration.
Bikes & Scooters: Can be booked up to 30 minutes in advance for an open-ended rental, lasting up to 12 hours.
Vehicle Management: All vehicles are equipped with GPS trackers. Cars and vans can be remotely disabled if necessary.
Return Process: Vehicles must be returned to designated parking spots. Cars and vans must be plugged into an EV charger. Customers are required to submit a photo of the returned vehicle as proof and can provide feedback on the vehicle’s condition.
Billing: Customers are charged per minute. Fines are automatically applied for returning a vehicle late or to an incorrect location.
Logistics & Maintenance: Our staff perform manual battery swaps for bikes and scooters and redistribute vehicles across our network to meet demand.

title: Scratch Notes
text:
2. Core Business Challenges
Despite our growth, we face significant operational inefficiencies and customer satisfaction issues that are hindering our potential. Our primary challenges are:

Inefficient Vehicle Distribution: Our most frequent customer complaint is that “the right vehicles aren’t in the right places.” We lack a systematic way to anticipate demand, leading to a poor customer experience and lost revenue. We need to move from a reactive to a predictive model for vehicle placement.
Reactive Maintenance & Charging: We struggle with vehicles running out of charge, particularly bikes and scooters that rely on manual battery swaps. Our staff’s efforts are not optimized; we need a way to prioritize which vehicles and charging bays require service most urgently to maximize fleet availability.
Ad-Hoc Customer Usage: The majority of our customers use our services on an ad-hoc basis. We have a strategic goal to increase customer loyalty and transform our service into a reliable option for regular, daily commutes.

title: Scratch Notes
text:
3. The Architectural Mandate
Our objective is to design a new target architecture for the MobilityCorp platform. The central requirement of this new architecture is the strategic incorporation of Artificial Intelligence (AI) to directly address the business challenges outlined above.
The proposed solution must detail how AI will be leveraged to:

Enhance the solution for MobilityCorp (the company):

Optimize vehicle distribution by predicting demand hotspots.
Create intelligent routing and task prioritization for maintenance staff (e.g., battery swaps, vehicle redistribution).
Provide analytics and insights into fleet performance and health.



Enhance the solution for our customers:

Improve vehicle availability and reliability.
Potentially create new features that encourage regular use, such as personalized commute planning or dynamic pricing.

Your team’s proposal should present a comprehensive architectural vision that is robust, scalable, and considers the real-world constraints and uncertainties of implementing AI-driven systems.

title: ADR-001
text: ADR-001: Choice of Event-Driven Architecture (EDA) Status: Accepted Context: The MobilityCorp system must handle a high volume of asynchronous, real-time events from thousands of vehicles (GPS updates, battery status) and users (bookings, returns). A traditional synchronous, request-response architecture would create tight coupling between services, leading to cascading failures and difficulty scaling individual components. Decision: We will adopt an event-driven architecture using a central message broker (e.g., Apache Kafka, Google Pub/Sub, AWS Kinesis). Services will communicate by producing and consuming events. For example, when a ride ends, the Booking Service publishes a RideEnded event. The Payment Service consumes this to calculate the bill, and the Smart Return Service consumes it to trigger photo analysis. Consequences: Pros: Enhances scalability, resilience, and loose coupling. Services can be developed, deployed, and scaled independently. New services can easily be added to consume existing event streams without modifying producer services. Cons: Introduces complexity in managing eventual consistency, monitoring distributed transactions, and handling event schema evolution. Requires robust dead-letter queue and retry mechanisms.

title: ADR-003
text:
ADR-003: Approach to Smart Return Verification
Status: Accepted Context: MobilityCorp requires proof of a correctly completed return, including vehicle location, connection to an EV charger, and condition. Manual verification is not scalable. Decision: We will implement a Smart Return Service that uses computer vision to analyze the photo submitted by the user at the end of a rental. The service will perform a multi-step analysis: Image Authenticity: Check image metadata to ensure it’s a recent photo taken at the time of return. Location Verification: Use image recognition to confirm the vehicle is at a designated parking spot (e.g., by recognizing background landmarks or signage). Damage Detection: Compare the return photo against a pre-rental photo (if available) or a baseline “healthy” image of that vehicle model to flag significant new damage. Connection Check: For EVs, analyze the image to detect the presence of a charging cable connected to the vehicle’s port. Consequences: Pros: Automates a critical business process, reducing operational costs and enabling rapid scaling. Provides immediate feedback to the customer. Creates a data trail for dispute resolution. Risks & Mitigations: Accuracy: False positives/negatives (e.g., flagging a shadow as damage) can lead to poor customer experience. Mitigation: The system will generate a confidence score. Low-confidence results or flagged issues will be automatically routed to a human review queue. The models will be continuously retrained on this human-labeled data. Environmental Factors: Poor lighting, bad weather, or low-quality photos can impact accuracy. Mitigation: The mobile app will guide the user on how to take a good photo (e.g., “Please ensure the entire side of the car is visible”). The system will be trained on a diverse dataset including various lighting and weather conditions. Data Privacy: User-submitted photos are personal data and must be handled according to GDPR. Mitigation: All photos will be stored securely with strict access controls. We will implement data retention policies to automatically delete photos after a set period.
